parameters.products: The Research Management Platform: Web-based software that provides access and tools for managing an expert network of 200,000 sources. Customers can also telephone a company Research Manager to identify and engage with appropriate experts.
parameters.key_people: Mark Gerson, Co-Founder and Executive Chairman Alexander Saint-Amand, President and Chief Executive Officer Thomas D. Lehrman, Co-Founder and Director

bdy.p: Gerson Lehrman Group (GLG) operates an expert network comprised of more than 200,0001 experts who provide consultant services to businesses. GLG’s clients include financial services firms, professional services firms, corporations, and non-profit organizations that use the network to improve their decision-making process.

GLG does not provide research or expertise itself but instead puts clients in touch with relevant experts. GLG Council Members include physicians, scientists, engineers, attorneys, senior-level business executives such as former CEOs, and market researchers. The GLG Councils are managed by Council Managers from GLG, who use a sophisticated set of profiling tools to help optimize matches with users.

sec.p: Gerson Lehrman Group was initially funded by a friends and family round.2

The firm has been called the "most valuable NYC company no one outside of
Wall Street
has ever heard of."3 Estimates of the company’s value range from $875 million to $950 million.4 A 12-month revenue figure of $220 million was included in a company press release in December 2007 that announced that technology investment firm Silver Lake had made an approximately $200 million investment in GLG.5

GLG was founded in 1998 by
Yale Law School graduate Mark Gerson and Thomas Lehrman, who had spent the prior two years at large hedge fund Tiger Management. Their new company was formed as a publishing house to produce industry guidebooks for institutional investors, a business they abandoned a year later when they could find no buyers for their product. The two retooled their business model a year later to offer a matchmaking service -- or expert network -- to connect investors with independent consultants who could answer questions about a specific industry. Its services filled a research gap by providing timely, proprietary insights that were increasingly difficult to get from large brokerage firms.6

As the use of alternative research providers within the financial industry has grown, brokerages themselves have seen the value of partnering with firms such as GLG.7 Today, there are at least 25 expert network providers focused on serving the investment community.8

GLG began working with clients outside of the investment community in 2005, and now has about 20,000-30,000 Council members who are senior business leaders engaged in consulting with other businesses.9 The company’s approach of connecting people and allowing for ranking of the experience involves a number of elements associated with social networking sites. There are some who consider the GLG model to be part of the evolving social network collaboration trend.10

In addition to Gerson Lehrman Group's headquarters in
New York City and other locations in major cities in the USA, the company operates in key cities around the world.11

Gerson Lehrman Group claims it facilitates more than 12,000 consulting engagements a month.12 This volume drives a ranking system for the experts, called CouncilRank. A typical phone consultation with an expert lasts for approximately 40 minutes.13
GLG’s home page states that it has 200,000 experts in its network. A competitor, Vista Research, is said to have a network of 90,000.14
Clients can identify the appropriate expert from within the network and manage the logistics around the consulting session via a Web-based software tool called the Research Management Platform.

Clients can also call a GLG Research Manager who will perform the search to find the appropriate expert(s). Clients can choose how they wish to interact with the chosen expert, such as over the phone, via an in-person meeting, or through the creation of a written report or survey.

Experts are invited to join the network based on their profiles or association with industry organizations. Experts can submit their profiles online, including biographical descriptions and other background information.

The company has a deal with
Credit Suisse , whereby analysts from the financial services giant would be able to tap into GLG’s council members as part of their research process. In return, 300 Credit Suisse analysts became members of the GLG expert network.15

The expert network business model has drawn scrutiny for concerns relating to adherence to disclosure rules and sharing of insider information within the investment industry.16 During 2005, for example, doctors who served as paid consultants to investment firms as a result of their role in an expert network generated a “fair share of controversy.”17

GLG was part of a lawsuit filed by
Biovail in March 2006, in which Biovail claimed that its shares had been manipulated.18

In September 2006, GLG announced a program of outreach to employers to increase transparency in the expert consulting and primary research fields. 19 GLG has in place a compliance framework and tools that are designed to supplement and enhance the compliance protocols of its clients and reduce client exposure to conflicts.20 The company says it has built proprietary systems to help identify and manage conflicts, leveraging its experience as a pioneer in its industry to craft risk-reducing rules for expert engagements.

In January 2007, it was reported that the company and Vista Research, then a Standard & Poor affiliate, were part of an inquiry by the New York State Attorney General’s office into the consulting practices of investment firm clients.21 In December 2007, The New York Times indicated that no action had been taken by the New York State Attorney General’s office and that the investigation was possibly dormant.22
